review_title: Good job for new techs. Good if you want to be trained in CT.
pros: Management is nice and is not strict. Workload is rarely too much. Enough patients to keep your day busy, but not out of control. Employees are all pretty decent.
cons:
No bonuses. Rarely ever get a raise. Only raises are hospital wide raises only on extremely good years. In some departments employees have gotten gifts instead of raises. Lead tech position constantly rotates. No one wants to work the lead tech position very long due to low pay.

 Some are older and getting lazy with age, but you mind your own business and your own work, and they will mind their own. 

They are building a new parking deck, but it is unsure who will have access. Currently the main parking during the day is a lot 5 blocks away from the hospital. A shuttle van moves employees and students from the lot to the hospital. Normal staff can only use parking deck on evening/overnight and weekend shifts. Many people park on the busy street. 

Unless you want to move up to be a CT tech or Lead Tech, there aren't many possibilities for advancement. Current management not willing to train people in new things outside of CT.

review_title: I just want full access on glassdoor so I'm writing this review
pros:
- Workload fairly light
- Decent PTO
- Health insurance is affordable
cons:
- Low pay
- Nepotism
- Lack of management

pros: I would like to say Team work, but there is teamwork at every other hospital also. So there is nothing exceptionally good, nothing worth noting as a pro for this hospital.
cons: Tripled every single day. Admission every single day even for non -icu pts admitted to the ICU. Lack of supplies. Lack of appreciation. Overworked, underpaid. I found out everyone leaves after a week or 2. If you're new, and even experienced, you will get the worst of the worst pt's, and they expect you to leave on time. God forbid you leave late cause you're tripled with an admission, and are actually doing your job, helping your pts, and doing everything right, not trying to risk your license , and they make a fuss and question why you are leaving late, and why you shouldn't be paid the hours that you actually worked.

job_title: Registered Nurse, Emergency Room in Elizabeth, NJ
pros: I learned a lot. I can not ever deny that it was a great experience in many ways. Great pay for a new nurse. Great benefits. Generous PTO. I had a lot of autonomy. I loved my coworkers. I was able to call a lot of shots. It was my first ER job and I went through the worst of COVID with them. I’ve become highly skilled in this specialty of nursing Because I learned how to improvise and how to work and do my job to the best of my capabilities despite the bad conditions with the lack of supplies and resources and of course every patient being Catastrophically ill with multiple comorbidities. It is a wonderful place to learn however I would not recommend working here at all. However every new grad needs a job. if you could get in anywhere else for your first job just do it.
cons: The ratio is 1 to 6 but that is a lot when you don’t even have a PCT to help you and you’re literally doing every little thing, Leaving very little time to do actual nursing duties such as medication assessment and documentation. The PCT’s that they do have are sadly ran to the ground and when they are asked to do something they don’t wanna hear it And most are usually hiding in the break room when you need them the most which aggravated the hell out of me when I couldn’t even have my lunch break. Also the management picks their favorites and allows bullying and hazing to take place. They are inconsistent with their rules were certain people get away with some things while other people don’t. If you are not in the in crowd with management they will not take care of you. They will not listen to your concerns. There are never enough supplies. Management will make you feel like you aren’t that great and don’t deserve better. But then when you try to leave They will scare you and say that every other emergency department is not as laid-back as them And that you won’t last anyplace else. The night time management is wonderful and always try their best but in general the whole place is inconsistent and disorganized and dangerous for your nursing license. There is no room for growth here! Maybe when Robert Wood takes over, things will get better.

pros: Interesting and meaningful job, good location
cons: Low salary and growth opportunities

pros: Great learning experience. Orientation was short but I learned so much in a short amount of time. That is why I came to this facility..... however the cons far outweigh the pros
cons: Once you are off orientation, you are on your own. You can't get any help from anyone because everyone is busy. Some won't help you because they are spiteful, others just can't because they don't have the time. Some nursing assistants are good, others are not. The floor is always understaffed, and if it is staffed properly, someone is getting floated to another floor. In some cases nursing assistants prefer to chat with each other rather than do their work. Bilingual should be a mandatory requirement. The goal of every nurse I have met has been to get out as soon as something better comes along. The pay is not even good. All the staff I have personally come across have stated they are unhappy. The hospital stands for quality patient care, however how could anyone provide good quality patient care when the floors are understaffed and the staff is overworked. Nurse/patient ratio is too high. Between 6 to 8 patients... more like 8 patients.

pros: Great nursing staff. Generally great to work alongside with as a team.
cons: Grossly understaffed with nursing assistant. Understaffed with CPA certified 1:1 personnel. Overworked nurses with 7 patients each. New rules appearing every week adding to the workload of the entire staff. Questionable new rule that puts patient's safety at risk (having potential nursing home candidates out of bed and into a chair in the morning, this high risk population moving around while still tired and asleep)

pros: As a new grad in the ED, I am grateful that I was given the opportunity to be part of this team.  It is challenging at times because it is an urban ED.  Management team is always willing to help and always working in the trenches with me.  There are some old nurses that need to go because they're so negative and set in their old ways.
cons: In need of new equipments- stretchers, IV carts.  We are Always running out of stretchers.  Security needs to be revamped.  They are not doing their job.

pros: TRMC has really been a great place to work. The managers and workers are all so friendly and are willing to help you with anything you may need. The experience and teaching received has been one of the best out of any jobs I’ve worked at. This is my first job in the healthcare field and feel very confident in my work and care given to each patient thanks to the wonderful education given by each and every employee and instructor that has been placed in my path. I would highly recommend TRMC for employment.
cons: Out of many nurses and employees I have only come in contact with maybe two employees who are a bit condescending but mean well.

review_title: Great co-workers, but low salaried employees
pros:
-Very supportive work environment with caring co-workers
- Mostly everyone cares about patients and their quality of care
- Benefits are better than most NJ hospitals from what I hear
- Behavioral Health is finally moving to EMR
cons:
- Salary is low
- Employee benefits are decreasing due to ever decreasing budget
- Older staff are set in their ways and resistant to change
- Working in older buildings and facilities that are in much-need of improvement and renovation

pros: There is nothing positive because everything is bad compared to what other hospitals provide.
cons: Time off are two weeks in which sick days, holidays are included. Thus, after holidays you have left one week, so you better have good health if you want to go on vacation! The company doesn't match employees contributions for the 401K plan which is really disappointing for a company that practically push their employees to send email to public servers to compain about Charity Care funding which is probably kept by high directives (this is based on the amount of Charity Care patients that come).

pros:
Most of my
coworkers I consider family.  This is one of few reasons I stayed despite the hourly rate both full time and per diem.  You are treated like family and with respect.  The hospital that I presently work full time, I dont get that warm vibe.  I learn more here than I do at my full time. Nurse managers and fellow rns push you to be successful.  good guidance
cons:
Policy for per diem: 2 weekends that you NEED OR OBLIGATED to work in a 4 week schdudle. 1 major holiday in the summer time and winter.  That is a lot for a per diem.  My current hospital along with you other competitors in your surrounding area does not have such requirments.  Most hospitals will require you to work at least ONE shift in a month.  

Here at Trini(trash) as most of you current and former employees would call TRMC,  per diem nurses feel forced to worn those 2 days.  That is why most of my per diem peers are quitting left and right. Necermind if your per diem rates are competitive,  surely people will work thaat required 2 weekends per schedule. Your per diem rates (specialty or non specialty units) are comparable to full time rates in other well known competitors in your area.  I stay employed here because of the people and leniency, if it werent for those 2, I would have quit a long time ago

review_title: I was displeased overall with my job experience.
pros: Helpful colleagues in my department only.
cons: Unprofessional and untrained manager. Dangerous work environment. Unprofessional and poorly trained security team. Condescending, emotionally detached medical staff (physicians and nurses in main emergency room) that seemed to have very little concern about patient experience. Poor communication amongst departments. Some staff allowed to create hostile work environment which was not addressed by the unit manager. Executive administration was disengaged and showed favoritism. Lack of department resources, wages were not competitive for behavioral health.

review_title: Great IT department, great leadership, poor pay
pros:
* Leadership within IT is fantastic. The IT directors and CIO curated a really good culture within the IT department. Firm, but human. Outside of IT, the other executives seemed to be really good people, especially the new CEO Scott Steiner. 

* Good campus. Cafeteria, vending machines, starbucks and a *VERY* nice employee gym. Could pay with your badge at Starbucks and the Cafeteria, and get a discount on the latter. Was typically cheaper to eat at the cafeteria than to make my own food at times. 

* Overall good organization. Everyone I worked with had patient care at the center of their focus.

* Despite the po-dunk community they're based in, Phoebe as a corporate unit does care about diversity and inclusivity. Lots of cultural, minority, and LGBT awareness.
cons:
* The compensation is far, far, FAR below national average across all of IT. The pay scale is incredibly antiquated, focusing on degrees, despite IT not being a degree focused career. Acquiring top industry certifications were overlooked. I ultimately left the company due to multiple offers equaling to double and triple what I was making.

* Speaking of underfunding, it was incredibly difficult to get approval for needed upgrades, systems, and staff for IT. Phoebe has bottomless pockets for patient care, which is good, but is extremely penny pinching with their technology. I believe this is a result of the antiquated and stereotypical executive mindset when it comes to IT.

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Albany, GA
pros: Phoebe has some solid staff. Good coworkers and team players were all around—down to the coffee shop barristas.
cons: Bullying is a problem in key areas and is not well handled.

pros:
- has recently increased starting base pay

cons:
- the scheduling on my floor
- having to be floated to another floor (nicu)

pros: There are no pro’s to working at Phoebe.

review_title: Great hospital to work for with a little room for improvement
pros: It's a great hospital.  The people who work here are mostly smart capable people who work as a team.  This is a growing organization that is increasing services offered and serves as a regional healthcare provider.  Phoebe is a progressive teaching hospital with a Family Medicine Residency Program and also trains medical students in conjunction with Medical College of Georgia.
cons: Promotions and recognition do not appear to be based on ability but more on who knows who.  Small group of people receive recognition for all good deeds regardless of who actually completes the tasks.  There are a lot of great folks making a few people look real good.  There appears to be high turnover in new hires and often times quality applicants don't get a second look.  Maybe HR has a hard time finding qualified recruiters to effectively hire the right person for the right job.  We lack qualified intelligent employees in some very visible front-line positions such as admitting--First impressions are everything.

pros: In this lab on this evening shift, the best reason to work here is my co-workers.  Everyone works as a team and everyone gets along.  The supervisor is great.  Also the MTs get a $2.50 shift diff.  This lab has good, up to date machines.
cons: Phoebe is always in trouble as they try to defeat competition from other hospitals in the 6 county area.  This hospital is in trouble with the Federal Trade Commission over their acquisition of Palmyra Hospital which is about 4 blocks from here.  The legal costs to fight this battle have been in the 10s of millions.  Phoegbe has had 2 lay offs in the last 12 months that included lab workers.

pros: State of the art facilities, forward thinking CEO, strong financial base. Clinical practice rooted in evidence based medicine. Uses E-ICU which enhances outcomes.
cons: Good old boy network exists in nursing leadership. Friendships have greater impact than talent and intellect. Able to talk a good game, but the follow through is lacking when it comes to moving nursing care forward.

job_title: Registered Nurse NICU in Albany, GA
pros: Only inpatient hospital in the area for certain specialties.
cons: High turnover, bad nurse:patient ratios, low pay relative to other regional towns such as Macon, Atlanta or Tallahassee, poor rural area for living, terrible insurance/benefits package, apathetic nursing management, poor yield relative to effort, low advancement potential.

pros: Excellent opportunity to gain experience in the medical field to learn billing, coding, and understanding of A/R and the financial structures associated with a myriad of insurances. Must possess the characteristics of being self motivated, innovative, persistent and the abillity to manage stress.
cons: Present salary range is not consistent with job duties and responsibilities. Unless a person is self motivated, innovative, persistent and can manage stress well, the job may become overwhelming. Due to a lack of appropriate training, the job can become frustrating and individual productivity can be threatened.

job_title: Patient Access Specialist in Albany, GA
pros:
Pay is average
Team Leaders are nice
cons:
Too many tasks for pay.
Management is very anal. 
You will never get to take those 15 minutes you're promised. 
Different people will tell you different things.
Nurses are rude. They're only nice when they want something.
EMT's try to rush you.
So many uncalled for tasks have to be done at the same time.
Management only care about shifts being filled. Even when shifts are short staffed they will not help you. 
They will call your desk phone from the other side of the hospital while you're trying to help patients.

pros: Work is not difficult. Coworkers are great and carry the department, even though most departments are top heavy with too much upper management or director levels.
cons: Low pay, high expectations. Elitist administration that still has the good old boy network...they promote or hire their buddies over better qualified or experienced candidates. Wastes money on special projects or consultants then never complete it. Haven't had raises in several years but insurance rates keep climbing while benefits and perks keep declining. Upper management is not held responsible. Departments are top heavy with too many director levels and above.

job_title: Certified Nursigg Assistant in Albany, GA
pros: Nurses and aides form good teams and work together to get the job done. The free gym had state of the art equipment and excellent classes. Starbucks in the lobby was nice too.
cons: Unrealistic expectations of upper management. Phoebe is an entity hat has gotten too big for its mission, and the business has become results driven Patient care comes second.

pros: Wonderful co-workers, excellent direct manager who is a very capable, well-respected nurse. Great atmosphere to work in. Employees treated fairly and honestly. Good benefits and compensation.
cons: None as far as staff or co-workers; everyone was more than courteous and capable. Some concerns regarding expansion of company, but seems to be advantageous to the firm.

review_title: Always get ahead with your education and certifications or you could be stuck!
job_title: Help Desk Analyst in Albany, GA
pros:
It is a decent starting point for your IT career. Most people entering the IT workforce with no IT experience start at Helpdesk or as a PC Technician. But it is very important to continue your education and gaining certifications for bigger positions.

They  work well with school schedules.

You can receive VISA gift card bonuses at the end of the year if the IT department is able to do so. I believe it is based of the amount of money the department as a whole has left over for bonuses and is based on the amount of hours you worked for the year. It does not happen every year though.
cons:
This position requires 3rd shifts if you are a per diem/part time employee. You will have to stay up overnight which became difficult for me to do after doing it so often.

Helpdesk as a whole gets overlooked for their hard work.  You can literally work your self to death and do your job very well but still get over looked but pointed out when you make the smallest mistake.

It is very difficult to advance your career here. Many of the upper level IT departments such as the Analyst department and IT Security departments are only there to help whoever they are friends with. They seem to look down upon the Helpdesk employees and can be "clickish". Not to sound bitter but if you can avoid this place, do so. I'm sure not all Helpdesk positions are like this.

pros: Pay is competetitve but only if you work weekends, nights and pool
cons: horrible management in surgical unit
